headline: What Nvidia's Vera Rubin AI platform brings to the table: CES 2026
summary: Nvidia (NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang showcased the chip manufacturer's future projects and partnerships in his CES 2026 keynote presentation, including the company's Alpamayo open-source AI model for autonomous vehicles and its Vera Rubin AI platform. Creative Strategies senior analyst Austin Lyons — alongside Freedom Capital Markets managing director Paul Meeks — sits down with Josh Lipton to explain what sets Nvidia's Vera Rubin apart from past AI architecture platforms. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: Marvell and Intel Stocks Are AI Buys, Says Analyst
summary: The AI trade faces doubts about whether it can last another year, but artificial intelligence also has its share of believers on Wall Street.  One is Ben Reitzes, an analyst at Melius Research, who upgraded  Marvell Technology  and  Intel  to Buy from Hold and assigning price targets to both stocks.  Marvell  came in at $135, and Intel at $50.

raw.headline: Marvell and Intel Stocks Are AI Buys, Says Analyst

Marvell  came in at $135, and Intel at $50.

headline: Nvidia CEO Huang to take stage at CES in Las Vegas as competition mounts
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is set to give a speech ​on Monday at the Consumer Electronics Show in ‌Las Vegas, potentially revealing new details about product plans for the world's ‌most valuable listed company as it faces increasing competition from both rivals and its own customers.  Less than two weeks ago, the company scooped up talent and chip technology from startup ⁠Groq, including executives who ‌were instrumental in helping Alphabet's Google design its own AI chips.  While Google is a ‍major Nvidia customer, its own chips have emerged as one of Nvidia's biggest threats as Google works closely with Meta Platforms and ​others to chip away at Nvidia's AI stronghold.

raw.headline: Nvidia CEO Huang to take stage at CES in Las Vegas as competition mounts
raw.summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is set to give a speech ​on Monday at the Consumer Electronics Show in ‌Las Vegas, potentially revealing new details about product plans for the world's ‌most valuable listed company as it faces increasing competition from both rivals and its own customers.  Less than two weeks ago, the company scooped up talent and chip technology from startup ⁠Groq, including executives who ‌were instrumental in helping Alphabet's Google design its own AI chips.  While Google is a ‍major Nvidia customer, its own chips have emerged as one of Nvidia's biggest threats as Google works closely with Meta Platforms and ​others to chip away at Nvidia's AI stronghold.

headline: US invades Venezuela, market reaction, CES kicks off: 3 Things
summary: Oil prices (CL=F, BZ=F) and related stocks rise following the US invasion of Venezuela and capture of President Nicolás Maduro. US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) inch slightly higher in Monday's premarket in response to the geopolitical headlines. CES 2026 kicks off today in Las Vegas with presentations from Nvidia (NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) CEO Lisa Su. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Following $1.5M Kickstarter Success, Olares to Debut NVIDIA 5090M-Powered "Personal AI Cloud" at CES 2026
summary: Olares, the innovator defining the "Personal AI Cloud" category, today confirmed its presence at CES 2026. Following a successful crowdfunding campaign, the team will unveil Olares One—a high-performance desktop AI powerhouse featuring the NVIDIA 5090M—at Booth 8268, LVCC North Hall, bringing uncompromised local intelligence directly to the show floor.

headline: Hush Security Selected for the 2026 CrowdStrike, AWS & NVIDIA Cybersecurity Startup Accelerator

headline: Markets show mixed reaction after US capture of Venezuelan leader
summary: Oil prices edged higher early Monday in Asian trading, while the prices of precious metals surged as markets registered a mixed reaction to the U.S. capture of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro in a weekend raid.  Share prices opened higher, with benchmarks in South Korea and Japan again setting fresh records.  Shortly after trading began, U.S. benchmark crude oil was up 12 cents at $57.44 per barrel, while Brent crude gained 14 cents to $60.89 per barrel.
